From Nov. 1st sleeping and dining cars on Egyptian State Railways are attached to ordinary trains from Cairo on Mon.; Wed. and Sat. at 3 p.m. and from Luxor on Tues, Thurs, and Sun. at 5.30 p.m.- From 2nd Dec. Luxe trains with sleeping and dining Cars will run on same day leaving Cairo and Luxor at 6.30 p.m. Early in Janurary these trains will be run daily. Express between Shallal and Halfa carry mails and 1st class passengers only, but 2nd class passengers may be accepted if accomodation is available. div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p:
The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between
Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to
Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation
for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry
proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent
Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to
Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor,
Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to
Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque)
begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the
Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the
scene of “Othello'' and of Ford's “Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus
in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.

Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook
& Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY,
General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

A children's dance and Christmas tree will be given at the Savoy Palace Hotel by the French Community of Alexandria on the 22nd inst. from 4 to 7 p.m.

New Year's Calendars. Messrs. Whitehead Morris & Co., the manufacting and export stationers and printers, of Alexandria and Cairo, are issuing some useful calendars and almanacs for the New Year to their numerous clients.

Sakhara Funds. The German exploration party now working Sakhara have recently been discovering some new tombs, though, as yet none of any first-rate importance, and there seem to be indications that the site of an ancient temple may soon be uncovered.

div.head: A CAIRO "CAUSE CELEBRE"
div.p: London, Wednesday. A decree nisi has been granted by the Divorce Division on the petition of Lord Vivian, who sought for a dissolution of his marriage with Lady Vivian on the ground of adultery. Mr. Alfred Curphey, the well- known Anglo-Egyptian financier, was the correspondent.

Lady Vivian was on of the belles of the last Cairo season and made a prolonged stay at the Savoy Hotel. She is the daughter of the late Mr. William A. Fanning and was married to Lord Vivian in 1903. There is one daughter and one son by the marriage.

Mr. Alfred Curphey arrived at Alexandria last Wednesday by the S.S. "Heliopolis" and after a brief visit to Cairo returned to Europe by the same steamer last Saturday. He is one of the directors of the Egyptian Mail steam ship company and has considerable financial interests in this country.

div.head: ANOTHER COTTON CRISIS
div.p: London, Wednesday. Another cotton crisis is threatened as the results of yesterday's mass meeting of the masters, which was of a warlike nature and seriously threatened that if two mills, present closed by a strike, are not working shortly the whole trade will stop. The masters intend to act as one man against the unjust demans of the work-people in the ring as regards spinners' wages. In the meantime business is being conducted under strike clauses, which haper international trade. The Board of Trade is watching affairs closely. Mr. Lloyd George will attend the meeting at Manchester if necessary.

div.head: Turkey's Troubles.
div.p: London, Wednesday. The "Daily Telegraph's" Constantinople correspondent announces that the ambassadors of the powers have handed a collective Note to the Sultan on the subject of Macedonia. The Note contains demands for the renewal of the Porte's agreements for another seven years in regard to the appointments of Civil Agents, Gendarmerie Officers and Financial Agents in Macedonia.

We regret to announce the death of Prince Ibrahim Pasha Fadel, at the age of 45 years. The funeral took place yesterday morning and was attended by the Princes of the Khedivial family and Ahmed Zakhy Pasha, Grand Master of Ceremonies to the Khedive.

div.head: The Esneh Barrage
div.p: It is only when one realizes the hundreds of men working upon them, the thousands of tons of material used in building them, the energies and years that are spent in their completion, that one begins to wonder if the modern barrage of Egypt will ever rank among the hoary monuments of the future as have the pyramids of the past: or whether they too will one day pass into nothingness like so many of the other great works of the country.

A visit to Esneh at the present moment will make one think of many things; but it is almost impossible to watch the scenes of activity, round the construction of momoth weir, without being reminded of similar scenes in byegone ages, when Egyptian kings were engaged in raising monumental works either for the good of the land or to their own glory. To-day there are the same ganges of busy workers swarming over the scene: only instead of slave labour groaning under a cruel yoke they are free men working for fair and honest wage and protected by many a modern institution. The ingenuity of the times has naturally supplied many labours saving contrivances unhead of in the past; but the Egyptian setting and the Egyptian type is still the same, and where the modern workman is left to his own devices he will use the same methods as did his far away ancestors.

div.head: Personal and Social
div.p: The Duke of Brunswick has left Cairo for a trip to Upper Egypt.
Prince d'Arenberg, Chairman of the Board of the Suez Canal Co. and M. Lepine, Prefect of the Parisian Police and also a director of the Canal Co. are due at Port Said from France on Friday next.
Sir Rudolph slatin Pasha is expected back at. Khartoum towards the end of the present month from his trip to the Eastern Sudan.
Lord Eustace Caeil and Mrs. Ceofl have returned to Egypt from Khartoum.
Laurs. Lady Grant will sail from Marseilles on the 20th for Cairo, where she will spend the winter. Lady Grant has let her house in Eaton-square to General Lyttelton till Easter.
Sir Thomas Lipton is due at Alexandria on Christmas eve by the S.S. "Heliopolis" and will stay at the Savoy Palace Hotel, where he will remain several days before proceeding to Cairo.
Mrs. Holland, of Benhall Lodge, Saxmundham, who has been staying at Cannes, has left for Egypt. She is accompanied by her son, her sister, Miss Rygate, and Miss Louise Vanneck.

div.head: Telegrams
div.p: Berlin, December 17. With regard to the persistent rumour that the Emperor and King Edward had decided to charge France with the entire responsibility of maintaining order in Morocco, it is stated here in official circles that during his Majesty's recent visit to Englad political questions were not discussed and the Moroccan question particularly has not been negociated either between the two Monarchs or governments. (Beuter)

div.head: Sultan's Jewels In Pawn.
div.p: Paris, December 17. The Mont de Piete has lent 1,250,000 francs on Sultan Abd el Aziz's jewels. (haves)
The state Pawnbroking Administration has advanced 1,250,000 francs on the sultan of morocco's jewels. (reuter)

div.head: The Secret Consistory
div.p: At the consistory the Pope deplored the attacks on the Church even by those who should safeguard it. He especially referred to the Italian pages in this connection. He denounced the Modernists. (Reuter)

div.head: Another Cotton Crisis
div.p: Manchester, December 17. The cotton EMployers Federation has decided on a general lockout unless the Ring Spinners' strikes at Oldham are settled within a reasonable time. (Reuter)

New York, December 17. A colliery explosion has occurred at Birmingham (Alabama). 35 bodies have been recovered. 70 persons have perished. This is the third terrible disaster within a fortnight. (Reuter)

Mogador, December 17. Mulay Hafid has played his last card in the unsuccessful attempt to retake Mazagan. The important Seragna tribe and others have abandoned Mulay Hafid and proclaimed Abd-el-Aziz and joined the latter's forces. Mulay Hafid is practically beleagured in Marrakesh. (Reuter)
Marnia, December 17. The Branlieres column has reached Cheraa and advanced as far as Mouluya. (Havas)
St. Petersburg, December 17. Fifty Redical journalists and 100 typographers have been arrested on account of a revolutionary organisation. (Havas)
Athens, December 17. In consequence of the students' agitation the University will close its doors. (Havas)
Athens, December 18. The Government has decided to close the University for two months on account of the students' resistance of compulsory gymnastics. (Reuter)
Sydney, December 17. Cricket England out for 300 runs. (Reuter)
Sydney, December 17. Second innings Australia 63 runs for 3 wickets. (Reuter)

div.head: Telegrams
div.p: Budapest, December 18. The Premier described the resolution passed in the Reichsrath, calling on Hungary to deal justly with her various nationalities, as an affront for which she must receive satisfaction. (Reuter)

Vienna, December 18. Reicharath, The Premier said that the government declined to carry out the resolution passed in the Reicharath. He begged the House to abstain from meddling with Hungarian affairs. (Reuter)
Lord Kelvin is sinking slowly. (later) Lord Kelvin is dead. (Reuter)

London, December 17. The "Times" learns from Teheran that the release of the Premier, who is a holder of a high British order, was due to the solicitation of the British Legation. In view of the seriousness of the news from Percia Great Britain and Russia are co-operating in taking steps to relieve the situation. (Reuter)

San Francisco, December 17. There are indications that the Californians intend to utilize the arrival of the battleships for the purpose of strengthening the anit- oriental agitation, and are organizing great demonstrations in honour of the fleet. (Reuter)
The weather yesterday was agreeable, but at night the wind rose the cold increased. This morning opens cloudy with a strong breeze from W.N.W. and a falling barometer.

div.head: Khedivial Mail Steamship Co.
div.p: The annual meeting of the Khedivial Mail Steamship and Graving Dock Company (Limited) was held on the 9th inst. at Wineheater House, Mr. Charles A. Hanson-presided.
The notice convening the meeting having been read by the secretary (Mr. L Holiday) the report and accounts (which have already appeared in the "Shipping Gazette,") were taken as read.

The Chairman: I am sure you will all join me in greatly regretting the absence from our meeting to-day, through severe and protracted illness, of our most capable and distinguished chairman, Sir Anchlaud Colvin, and I have no doubt it will be your wish that I should convey to him an expression of your sincere sympathy and of our best wishes for his early and complete recovery. The year which ended on June 30 last was, I am glad to say on the whole a satisfactory year. In comparison with 1905-1906 the traffic earnings have shown increases from almost every service worked by the company. and from almost every source of revenue which has been available to the company. The only rexceptions which I think can be made to this general rule and the earnings from the Suez factory, from the floating dock at Alexandria, and from the revenue derived from the international mail service. In these items there have been decreases but, the decreases are trifling and of no serious importance.

In analysing the accounts for the year we find that the lagest increase of revenue has come to us from the pilgrim trade, which last year luckily happened to be exceptionally good. The pilgrim trade, as you are probably aware, is an omportant branch of our service, and is an important source of revenue, but in this, as in all other departments of trade and traffic, there are good years and bad years, and sometimes it may happen that our carrying power is taxed to its utmost capacity with large earnings, while at other times our tonnage may be largely in excess of the requirements with coreesponginly small earnings, This pilgrim trade is, however, an extremely onerous trade, as we are obliged to provide for every emergency and to make our organisation and service as perfect as possible to satisf the exacting requirements of the Government of Egypt, and to secure for the satifation of the pilgrims themselves that they are carried with safety and comfort.

div.head: Devidend
div.p: The net Restrit of the whole year is that, notwithstanding our increased expenditure both for ordinary account and special repairs to ships, and leaving also provided an additional fund for extraordinary depreciation, we are still able to recommend to you the declaration of a dividend at the rate of 10 per cent. per annum, and to carry forward to the next year's accounts a trifle over 13,000l. I hope you will consider this on the whole a not unsatifactory record.

Referring again to the report, I may perhaps be permitted to refer to the paragraph wich relates to the issue of new capital. You will recollect that a year ago the directors asked you for additional capital powers, and you very generously accessed to our request. At that time two facts were prominent in our minds, viz : First, the necessity for building two or three new first class steamers. Secondly, the necessity of finding the funds for building these vessels, and for other capital purposes, by an issue of new capital. At that time the financial sky was comparatively unclouded. The financial condition of Egypt particularly appeared to be eminently satisfactory, and we were assured and had reason to believe that Egypt was eager to join with London in finding this capital at an appreciable premium upon its par value, and at such a premium as would be satisfactoru to the directors: and there is no doubt, indeed, that had we been in a position at the time to take advantage of that situation, we should have been able to issue our capital successfully and with great advantage to the company. Things, however, changed rapidly, and when we were ready the markets were less favourable- so much less favourable, indeed, that the directors did not deem it an opportune moment to place the shares upon the maket.

div.head: Army and Navy.
div.p: London, December 10. As has been already intimated in these notes, Colonel R. ©. Cox will vacate the com- mand of the 2nd Battalion Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, Alexandria, on the 26th prox. on completion of his four years at its head. Co- lonel Cox got his first commission iy the old 27th Inniskillings in June, 1879, got his com- pany in 1887 and majority in 1898. He served with the Ist Battalion in the South African war, and commanded it for the last two years of the stuggle with much ability in the fighting in the Transvaal, Orange River Colony and Cape Colony (mentioned in despatchesm brevet Lieutenant Colonelcy, Queen's medal with five clasps)

Major H.O.D. Hickman, second in command of the 1st Battalion, Crete, has been selected for the command of the 2nd Battalion, the step going to him in the usual course, he being the senior major of both battalions. Major Hickman is a very smart and popular officer and a staff college man as well. HE has spent since Janurary 1890 in the Inneskillings, and prior to that he was nine years in the Green Howards. He was attached to the Egyptian Army from 1885 to 1889, a portion of which time he was Assissant Military Scretary to the Sirdar so that his previous Egyptian service will be in his favour when he goes to the head of the 2nd Battalion. He served in the Nile Expedition, 1884-85 (medal with clasp,star); Soudan campaign, 1888, including the action Gemaizah (clasp, th class Medjidie); and the South African war 1901-02, inclusive of the actions of Belfast and Lydenburgh and the operations in Cape Colony, Natal, and the Transvaal (Queen's medal with two clasps).

Apres avoir pris connaissance d'une nouvelle note de L'Ingenieur en chef, relative aux avantages qu'il y aurait a recouvrir en briquettes d'asphalte la chaussee du pont route de la rue No.3, la delgation decide l'adoption de ce mode de pavage sur une superficie de 200 m.c. environ et autorise a cet effet une depense s'elevant dans sa totalite a L.E. 100.

div.head: Bulletin De La Bourse.
div.p: Notre marche, beacoup sans doute a cause de la situation generale et un peu a cause de 'approche des fetes correspondant aux inventaires, est tombe dans un etat de depression et d'accalmie completes. La place parait saturee de titres et les agents commencent a se fatiguer de sa passer les paquests les uns aux autres pour donner a la corbeille un semblant d'animation. Le fait est que la matinee a ete deplorable su double point de vue des transactions et des fluctuations. Tout le monde est vendeur et la contre- pagtie est presque introuvable. On ne sait quand prendra fin cette immobilite penible, mais on n'espere pas de relevemnt appreciable pour la fin de l'annee; on s'attend plutot a une accentuation de la faiblesse. Dans de telles conditions les affaires se limitent a des proportions insgnifiantes et la plupart des valeurs abordees s'inscrivent en nouvelle baisse.

Nautrellement les valeurs dirigeantes sont delaissees avec une legere depreciation: Ainsi l'Agricole flechit de 7 25/32 a 7 ¾, la National Bank de 20 1/16 a 2 la Daira de 12 ¾ a 12 5/8 et L'obligation ancienne Credit Foncier de 284 ½ a 282 ½. Seule de cette categorie, la Delta Light, a la faveur d'une demande, reprend de 9 9/16 a 9 5/8.

div.head: Vade Mecum for the Homeward Bound
TO OUR VISITORS
div.p:
The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the
accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which
they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as
accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them
are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several
things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate
between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in
January may be a little warmer than the Riviera and possibly not so warm as
Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm
than many other places in Europe.

Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather
in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is
Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at
sea, and we therefore subjoin a list shewing the time occupied on each of
the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.

The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton,
London or Liverpool—occupy about 14 days. The short ones are as
follows:—

The steamers of the P.&O., the Egyptian Mail S.S,. Co., North German
Lloyd, Orient, and Messageries Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor,
British India, Bibby and Henderson Lines are also excellent, and their
steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.

As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria,
without change (3 hours). That to Port Said can now be made without change
in 4 ½ hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and
Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant
line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.

The quickest through Continental routes are by P.&O. Brindisi express
from Port Said, by the Egyptian Mail S.S. Co., from Alexandria to Marseilles
and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage
is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and
responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to
deliver packages to any address in Europe. The Egyptian Mail S.S. Co., have
also made arrangements whereby luggage can be collected and sent to any
address.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the
fast Mail Steamers “Osiris" and “Isis” to Brindisi. One of these
leaves Port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian
mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and
attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having
been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi.
If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting
at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete
arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in
London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p:
The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.’s steamers which
leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one
of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to
Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the
town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but
restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of
Etna, and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic
remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of
pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city,
which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in
B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral
was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants,
is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of
interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo
Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque
cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal
Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p:
The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday
during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.’s
steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without
wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its
bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can
drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will
devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting
portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known
to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours
brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the
City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In
Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst
the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in
Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the
finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the
hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside
Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is
made first by ordinary train from Florence to St.
Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most
striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; here there is a fine
Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if
possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at
sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa
and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way
house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air
and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p:
GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with
the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and
a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool
breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy’s most ancient nobility, whose palaces,
gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a
constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa.
Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite
marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo
filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the
Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows
illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental
cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is
SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs,
change trains at Borgo San Domino and in half-an-hour
you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p:
VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most
delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of
vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange; no horse, cart, carriage or
bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The
approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port.
The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea. No hills
behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above
the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage
out of the calm lagoon.

Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the
beautiful Italian lakes.

COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter
hours by train by way of Monza.

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very
beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most
enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo
along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most
enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour,
then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p:
Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described
as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half
hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on
the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San
Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty
town, situated at the top of Lake Maggiore, has a mild climate and is an
excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the
town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, “Entombment,"
by Ciseri, and ‘Tho Flight into Egypt,” by Bramantion.

LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus
and the snow-clad Alps.

In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made
from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions,
those to the Rigi, Pilatus,
Burgenstock and Sonnenberg
needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by
steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight
to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of
Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the
Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse.

THUN (on the Lake of Thun) half an hour from Berne and one hour from
Interlaken. Quiet and quaint; sheltered from winds; just the place to rest
and recuperate. Beautiful walks, through woods, and along the lake shore.
Kursaal, Concernts, Casino, Races, Tennis, Boating, etc.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND. – INTERLAKEN, a favourite summer resort and the best
centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and
views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau
from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees, the chief resort of
visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights
not to be missed.

CHATEAU D’OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between
Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry
air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

ZURICH on the Gothard route. Direct communication with Northern Europe.
Largest town in Switzerland, beautifully-situated on the lake of Zurich.
Theatres. Big Concern Halls. Boating on the lake. Excellent schools. The
National Museum.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p:
Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached
from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are
those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

It is hardly necessary to point out to Tourists the extraordinary interest of
a visit to Athens from an artistic, historical and archaelogical point of
view, and if possible tourists should average to be in Athens for the
Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve
ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival
held at Megara, for which a special train is run from Athens.

It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of
the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.

div.head: VENICE
div.p:

CLIMATIC STATION AND SEA BATHS, WITH CHINESITHERAPIC INSTITUTE. Express

The most important bathing station in Italy, Café-Restaurant and Terrace

Adjoining the sea. First-class hotel with dependencies & Chalets. 200
rooms & saloons. Electric light. Aqueduct. Every modern comfort.
Delightful residence, without any mosquitos.

Hotel with its dependencies (Swiss Hotel) in the most delightful

div.head: Vade Mecum for the Homeward Bound
TO OUR VISITORS
div.p:
The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the
accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which
they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as
accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them
are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several
things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate
between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in
January may be a little warmer than the Riviera and possibly not so warm as
Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm
than many other places in Europe.

Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather
in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is
Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at
sea, and we therefore subjoin a list shewing the time occupied on each of
the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.

The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton,
London or Liverpool—occupy about 14 days. The short ones are as
follows:—

The steamers of the P.&O., the Egyptian Mail S.S,. Co., North German
Lloyd, Orient, and Messageries Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor,
British India, Bibby and Henderson Lines are also excellent, and their
steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.

As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria,
without change (3 hours). That to Port Said can now be made without change
in 4 ½ hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and
Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant
line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.

The quickest through Continental routes are by P.&O. Brindisi express
from Port Said, by the Egyptian Mail S.S. Co., from Alexandria to Marseilles
and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage
is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and
responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to
deliver packages to any address in Europe. The Egyptian Mail S.S. Co., have
also made arrangements whereby luggage can be collected and sent to any
address.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the
fast Mail Steamers “Osiris" and “Isis” to Brindisi. One of these
leaves Port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian
mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and
attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having
been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi.
If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting
at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete
arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in
London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p:
The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.’s steamers which
leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one
of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to
Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the
town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but
restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of
Etna, and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic
remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of
pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city,
which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in
B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral
was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants,
is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of
interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo
Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque
cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal
Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p:
The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday
during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.’s
steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without
wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its
bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can
drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will
devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting
portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known
to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours
brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the
City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In
Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst
the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in
Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the
finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the
hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside
Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is
made first by ordinary train from Florence to St.
Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most
striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; here there is a fine
Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if
possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at
sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa
and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way
house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air
and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p:
GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with
the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and
a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool
breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy’s most ancient nobility, whose palaces,
gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a
constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa.
Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite
marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo
filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the
Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows
illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental
cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is
SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs,
change trains at Borgo San Domino and in half-an-hour
you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p:
VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most
delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of
vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange; no horse, cart, carriage or
bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The
approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port.
The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea. No hills
behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above
the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage
out of the calm lagoon.

Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the
beautiful Italian lakes.

COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter
hours by train by way of Monza.

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very
beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most
enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo
along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most
enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour,
then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p:
Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described
as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half
hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on
the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San
Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty
town, situated at the top of Lake Maggiore, has a mild climate and is an
excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the
town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, “Entombment,"
by Ciseri, and ‘Tho Flight into Egypt,” by Bramantion.

LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus
and the snow-clad Alps.

In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made
from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions,
those to the Rigi, Pilatus,
Burgenstock and Sonnenberg
needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by
steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight
to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of
Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the
Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse.

THUN (on the Lake of Thun) half an hour from Berne and one hour from
Interlaken. Quiet and quaint; sheltered from winds; just the place to rest
and recuperate. Beautiful walks, through woods, and along the lake shore.
Kursaal, Concernts, Casino, Races, Tennis, Boating, etc.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND. – INTERLAKEN, a favourite summer resort and the best
centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and
views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau
from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees, the chief resort of
visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights
not to be missed.

CHATEAU D’OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between
Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry
air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

ZURICH on the Gothard route. Direct communication with Northern Europe.
Largest town in Switzerland, beautifully-situated on the lake of Zurich.
Theatres. Big Concern Halls. Boating on the lake. Excellent schools. The
National Museum.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p:
Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached
from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are
those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

It is hardly necessary to point out to Tourists the extraordinary interest of
a visit to Athens from an artistic, historical and archaelogical point of
view, and if possible tourists should average to be in Athens for the
Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve
ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival
held at Megara, for which a special train is run from Athens.

It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of
the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.
